statements.name: PROC HTSNP
statements.description: Single nucleotide polymorphism (SNP) is the most abundant form of genetic variation and accounts for about 90% of human DNA polymorphism. There is roughly one SNP per 1 kilobase in the human genome. Studies of human haplotype variations that use SNPs over large genomic regions suggest the presence of discrete blocks with limited haplotype diversity punctuated by recombination hot spots. The intrablock linkage disequilibrium (LD) decreases only gradually with distance, while the interblock LD decays much more rapidly. Within each block, because of high LD, some allele(s) might always be coexistent with a particular allele at another locus such that (1) little haplotype diversity exists in the block, and (2) not all SNPs will be essential in characterizing the haplotype structure in the block. Therefore, the most common haplotypes could usually be captured by a small subset of SNPs, termed haplotype tagging SNPs (htSNPs) by Johnson et al. (2001).

arguments.name: CONV=
arguments.description: Specifies the convergence criterion for search of htSNPs, where 0 < number ≤ 1. The search process is stopped when the haplotype criterion is greater than or equal to number specified in the CONV= option. The default value is 0.90. When METHOD=SA or METHOD=EX is specified, the CONV= option is ignored and the searching continues until the annealing schedule is finished or the whole search space is traversed.

arguments.name: CRITERION=
arguments.description: Indicates the criterion to use for evaluating candidate sets of htSNPs. By default, CRITERION=PDE.

arguments.name: PDE
arguments.description: The proportion of diversity explained (PDE) is used (Clayton 2002).

arguments.name: RSQH
arguments.description: Stram et al.’s R²h is used to measure haplotype richness (2003).

arguments.name: CUTOFF=
arguments.description: Specifies a lower bound on a haplotype’s frequency in order for that haplotype to be included in the search process for sets of htSNPs. The value of number must be between 0 and 1. By default, all haplotypes from the sample are included in the search process.

arguments.name: DATA=
arguments.description: Names the input SAS data set to be used by PROC HTSNP. The default is to use the most recently created data set.

arguments.name: MAXSIZE=
arguments.description: Specifies the maximum number of markers to be included in the subset for incremental search by default or when METHOD=INCR is specified. The number must be a positive integer that is less than or equal to the number of markers specified in the VAR statement. Searching is carried out until convergence is reached according to the convergence criterion, or until number of markers have been included in the subset.

arguments.name: METHOD=
arguments.description: Indicates the method used for core marker set selection. By default, METHOD=INCR.

arguments.name: INCREMENTAL
arguments.description: The incremental search algorithm is used.

arguments.name: DECREMENTAL
arguments.description: The decremental algorithm is used.

arguments.name: EXHAUSTIVE
arguments.description: The exhaustive search algorithm is used.

arguments.name: ITERMAX
arguments.description: The iterative maximization algorithm is used.

arguments.name: SIMANNEAL
arguments.description: The simulated annealing search algorithm is used.

arguments.name: NOSUMMARY
arguments.description: Suppresses the display of the "Marker Summary" table.

arguments.name: SCHEDULE=
arguments.description: Specifies the number of reconfigurations used in each annealing step when METHOD=SA. The value for number must be a positive integer. The default value is 100x(number of variables specified in the VAR statement).

arguments.name: SEED=
arguments.description: Specifies the initial seed for the random number generator used for the sampling of markers. The value for number must be an integer; the computer clock time is used if the option is omitted or an integer less than or equal to 0 is specified.

arguments.name: SIZE=
arguments.description: Specifies the size of the subset of markers to select. The value for number must be a positive integer that is less than or equal to the number of markers specified in the VAR statement. The SIZE= option must be specified for an exhaustive search, iterative maximization search, and simulated annealing search.

arguments.name: STEP=
arguments.description: Specifies the steps used for simulated annealing search when METHOD=SA. The value for number must be a positive integer. The default value is 1.

arguments.name: TEMPERATURE=
arguments.description: Specifies the temperature used for the simulated annealing search when METHOD=SA is specified. The value for number must be a positive number. The default value is 1.

arguments.name: TFACTOR=
arguments.description: Specifies the factor by which the temperature is reduced for each annealing step during simulated annealing search when METHOD=SA. The value for number must satisfy 0 < number < 1. The default value is 0.90.

statements.name: BY
statements.description: You can specify a BY statement with PROC HTSNP to obtain separate analyses on observations in groups defined by the BY variables. When a BY statement appears, the procedure expects the input data set to be sorted in the order of the BY variables. The variables are one or more variables in the input data set.

arguments.name: DESCENDING
arguments.description: Specifies that the observations are sorted in descending order by the variable that immediately follows the word DESCENDING in the BY statement.

arguments.name: NOTSORTED
arguments.description: Specifies that observations are not necessarily sorted in alphabetic or numeric order.

statements.name: FREQ
statements.description: The FREQ statement identifies the variable that indicates the frequency for each haplotype. If there is no FREQ statement, the frequency of each distinct haplotype is calculated by dividing its count by the total haplotype count. When a frequency value is missing or negative, the corresponding haplotype is ignored.

statements.name: VAR
statements.description: The VAR statement identifies the variables, one for each marker, containing the marker alleles that construct the haplotypes. Two or more variables must be specified.
